249365: Deep Analysis.author: DarthParallax
249365: Deep Analysis.text_parsed:
EDIT: ok, so actually it's 6 mana to get 4 cards-- except you divide it over 2 casts, and since this one has a smaller flashback cost than hard cast cost, that extra two mana will be much less costly than if it were just '4UU: draw 4 cards'. You can flash this back by turn 5 using just '1 basic per turn' mana, a full turn earlier than a '4UU: draw 4' would do. AND drawing 2 cards twice is probably better than drawing 4 all at once. I can't entirely explain well why I think that, but reading a bunch of different blue cards and thinking about it, it sounds right.


When you're evaluating how much your really paying and getting, I would say this is comparable to a 3UU Instant card that draws 3. It's a little bit slow, but you do get good value for your mana.


One final note. Bolas is a jerk. He probably casts this on turn 2 off a Sol Ring all day long ;)

249365: Deep Analysis.author: Kryptnyt
249365: Deep Analysis.text_parsed:
I don't know about an Innistrad reprint.
They used Nicol Bolas in this art, and he doesn't seem to have a stake in Innistrad at all. If they planned on reprinting it they probably would have used the art from the new set, to save money.
Still, that hardly means anything. Just my gut.

On the card itself, its really solid. Playing it from your hand is a little pricey, but the flashback means you can discard it (like, to Psychatog, for instance) and get some extra value with your blue Sign in Blood. If it were reprinted in standard right now, you could put it in a deck along with Mulch and Forbidden Alchemy and get tons of value. A Burning Vengeance deck would profit from it too.

Few draw spells are this versatile.

249366: Firemane Angel.author: Cyberium
249366: Firemane Angel.text_parsed:
For starter, Firemane is a solid creature in play with both flying and fire strike. Her graveyard ability allows burden-free discard/sacrifice effects. One could use cards like Peace of Mind to dump her into graveyard then use the repeating life gain to power Searing Meditation and Ajani's Pridemate. Her reanimation ability, while expensive, will come in handy when you need a creature.

All in all, Firemane is a good card that serves perpetual purpose. She cannot dominate the field like a Baneslayer but Firemane's versatility makes her an easier card to combo with.

249366: Firemane Angel.author: DarthParallax
249366: Firemane Angel.text_parsed:
Firemane's hard costing is about right. I think it just needs a little bit more oomph to really really make it feel worth playing, but if you don't have cards that can work together, you don't have much of a deck. Behemoth Sledge is a good equip option, Ajani's Mantra as Cyberium suggested is not bad. I would have wanted to stick either Firebreathing on it, or make the grave ability also deal 1 damage, but hey- it's still playable.

2 colored rares shouldn't be quite as good as 1-color mythics for the same price, but they should be a good deal better than 1-colored rares. but, it's non-legendary....it's already got a pretty full textbox. It's kind of sad when a big giant angel creature summon isn't as exciting as a little zap spell like Lightning Helix.

if only the reanimation were cheaper! please. :P

249368: Woolly Thoctar.author: kiseki
249368: Woolly Thoctar.text_parsed:
A riddle:
You are playing a goldfish, on each turn you play a basic land, you may cast one creature in total, and cannot use the land for anything other than casting the creature. What is the fastest that you can kill your opponent?
This kills your opponent turn 7, as can Lost Leonin and Slith Firewalker. Is anything faster than turn 7? There are at least three shades that can do it by turn 6 if you allow use of the land. But is there another way to get under 7?
249368: Woolly Thoctar.text_posted:
A riddle:
You are playing a goldfish, on each turn you play a basic land, you may cast one creature in total, and cannot use the land for anything other than casting the creature.  What is the fastest that you can kill your opponent?  
This kills your opponent turn 7, as can [autocard]Lost Leonin[/autocard] and [autocard]Slith Firewalker[/autocard].  Is anything faster than turn 7?  There are at least three shades that can do it by turn 6 if you allow use of the land.  But is there another way to get under 7?

249368: Woolly Thoctar.author: pedrodyl
249368: Woolly Thoctar.text_parsed:
if you count commander cards, Ruhan of the Fomori gets the job done turn 7
also desecration elemental works nicely turn 7
if you can discard, which you probably can, avatar of discord t7
drinker of sorrow t7
mijae djinn t7 if you win the flips
phylactery lich t7 if you're allowed artifact lands
the classic phyrexian negator t7
ruinous minotaur t7
phyrexian vatmother t7
viashino sandstalker t7
viashino cutthroat t7
pardic dragon can t6 w/ firebreathing and the suspend
tempting wurm can t6
if you have three others in hand, Tarox Bladewing can t5
and since you are playing a goldfish who doesn't know how to play magic and block, hunted horror does it turn 5

249368: Woolly Thoctar.author: ICEFANG13
249368: Woolly Thoctar.text_parsed:
Although Thallid won't win when they are at 20, if they are at 22 then its the fastest 'single' creature killer at CMC 1. And he gets better than Woolly if you the target is at higher healths.

Assuming your health could be anything, then Death's Shadow is a turn 2 or 3 win (depending if you allow for -health for any reason) but I assume you are at 20 as well.

Leveler is a turn 7 win if not being able to draw doesn't make you lose.

Etched Monstrosity is turn 7 since you could remove its counters next turn before you attack.

Greater Gargadon is kinda close, since you could sac the lands and get it to kill 8.

Boldwyr Heavyweights is turn 7 since your opponent doesn't have creatures. Same with Desecration Elemental.

Thunderblust is turn 7 thanks to Haste.

Does he have cards? Turn 6 with Nyxathid

Turn 7 Phyrexian Hydra that gives me an idea.
Turn 6 Ogre Menial

249368: Woolly Thoctar.author: Axelle
249368: Woolly Thoctar.text_parsed:
If you can use mana for activated abilities, then T6 Ludevic's Test Subject. Alternately, if you can use the lands' non-mana-producing activated abilities, then Glistener Elf + Pendelhaven is T6.

Kruin Outlaw and Instigator Gang are T7 when transformed. An Allosaurus Rider played on T1 is a T6.

Also, loophole exploitation: On T5, cast 4 Pact of the Titans and Urabrask, the Hidden, then swing with Urabrask and all 4 of your Titans for T5 game. Pact of the Titan is not casting a creature, and you are not using the lands for anything other than casting the creature. Alternately, Summoner's Pact + Progenitus + Blazing Shoal + Glistener Elf is a T2. Heck, two Blazing Shoals, two Summoner's Pacts or Progenituses, and any one-drop is a T2.

Other loophole exploitation says that you can use mana produced only from creatures to play more creatures. You could try casting Grand Architect on turn 3, then using it to play Myr Superion. However, that would be a T7, and there are probably better ways to exploit that loophole.

249368: Woolly Thoctar.author: zenuedite
249368: Woolly Thoctar.text_parsed:
I was bored, so I scoured gatherer. Here's some T5s:

Student Of Warfare
T1: Plains, Student
T2: Plains, LvUp->2, 3 damage
T3: Plains, LvUp->5, 3 damage (6)
T4: LvUp->7, 8 damage (14)
T5: 8 damage (22)

Flailing Soldier
T1: Mountain, Soldier
T2: Mountain, Buff+2, 4 damage
T3: Mountain, Buff+3, 5 damage (9)
T4: Mountain, Buff+4, 6 damage (15)
T5: Mountain, Buff+5, 7 damage (22)
(Assuming your goldfish opponent can't be bothered to tap their unused mana)

I've looked at pretty much every creature ever that could be a potential on-its-own win, because I was bored, but I've pretty much come to the conclusion that T5's about the best you're going to do (this assumes no spells whatsoever other than the creature, and only basic lands. No opponent interaction.)

There's still a theoretical Turn 4 win with Mindshrieker, if the total CMC of the cards milled after three ability uses (one on T3 and two on T4) is 18 or more (That's 6 each, which isn't beyond plausibility).

249368: Woolly Thoctar.author: CorkBulb
249368: Woolly Thoctar.text_parsed:
EDIT: Oh nevermind. I just realized we are discussing *single* creatures winning *on their own* without being buffed by other spells :/

You all must realize that this discussion is awefully unrealistic since your opponents will most likely have played creatures and/or removal cards. That Wolly Thoctar is gonna get nailed by something as soon as it hits the table.

Anyway, as for the card, the 5/4 body for 3CMC is awesome, but it does require to play. Mana accel won't help here because most of the boost early on produce a tapped land or more green or colorless mana. It's a beatstick that usually causes alot of panic for your opponents if played on turn 3. In a Naya deck this is a must, especially with all those lovely white/red removals and buff spells. For mono-green, we now have Leatherback Baloths for 3CMC, all green but still 3. I'd love to see this thing fight a leatherback baloth, that would be awesome.

4.5/5 for what it is, a 5/4 creature

249368: Woolly Thoctar.author: JJBrazman
249368: Woolly Thoctar.text_parsed:
Turn 5 - Hunted Horror although that's relying rather heavily on your opponent literally being a goldfish, which is probably a bit much.

If you're very lucky you can do it turn 6 with Wolf-Skull Shaman.

Besides those (and others mentioned in other comments) I'm struggling to find any that do it in less than 7.

Many of you seem to have missed the clause 'You cannot use the lands for anything other than casting the creature'. Really this means that you can't spend mana for anything else at all as the two other ways to get mana are creature abilities (which would only be useful if that creature had a separate game winning ability that costs only marginally more mana which would be broken) and 0 mana accelerators such as Black Lotus which are technically not against the rules laid out, but 4 black lotuses into Blightsteel Colossus is a cheap way to win turn 2). So let's assume you can't spend mana for ANYTHING other than casting the creature

This means that most activated abilities are out the window because, to be worth it, they would have to (without cost) do one of three things:

Heavily and directly damage your opponent (as in at least the 'required powers' below per pop) which, since it's essentially just an unblockable attack, would be broken.

Produce a token (or creature) capable of winning the game for you; a really slow way to go since you lose 2 turns to summoning sickness rather than the usual 1. Note that Marit Lage (unfortunately) requires a non-basic land.

Permanently buff the creature itself into a game winner. Note that it would have to add at least its starting power in permanent buff to be worth using the ability and not simply attacking. A likely creature? I think not.

Note that I'm assuming that this cost involved tapping in the above. While not technically a requirement I'd be surprised if you could find a competitive ability that didn't require it. The only other costs you could likely pay are life (the absolutely tiny selection of competitive life-for-damage cards are all well known and not sufficient) or cards (you can only discard 5 if you're going to hit every land drop, as required. That lets Wild Mongrel win on turn 10).

So activated abilities are out. How about direct damage, with only static abilities?

Assuming you want to win in less than 7 turns...
A one drop would need at least 4 power.
A two drop would need 4 power with haste, or 5 without haste.
A three drop would need 5 with, or 7 without.
A 4 drop: 7 with, 10 without.
5 drop: 10 with, 20 without.
6 drop: 20 and would need haste.

Clearly none of these exist.

I should, as an aside, point out that I've checked every infect card (and every unleashed card, for good measure). Some make it on turn 7, none are faster.

Although this is hardly proof, I think it's pretty conclusive evidence that you need a triggered ability, and possibly a static ability or three to go with it.

So, basically, it's time to trawl Gatherer for the best triggered abilities; my guess is that it's worth looking for damaging ETB effects, counter accumulators (Scute Mob is T7) or Token makers (although I've checked most of those).
Who knows though; the possibilities are virtually endless!
249368: Woolly Thoctar.text_posted:
Turn 5 - [autocard]Hunted Horror[/autocard] although that's relying rather heavily on your opponent literally being a goldfish, which is probably a bit much.

If you're very lucky you can do it turn 6 with [autocard]Wolf-Skull Shaman[/autocard].

Besides those (and others mentioned in other comments) I'm struggling to find any that do it in less than 7.

Many of you seem to have missed the clause 'You cannot use the lands for anything other than casting the creature'. Really this means that you can't spend mana for anything else at all as the two other ways to get mana are creature abilities (which would only be useful if that creature had a separate game winning ability that costs only marginally more mana which would be broken) and 0 mana accelerators such as Black Lotus which are technically not against the rules laid out, but 4 black lotuses into Blightsteel Colossus is a cheap way to win turn 2). So let's assume you can't spend mana for ANYTHING other than casting the creature

249369: Lead the Stampede.author: hansede
249369: Lead the Stampede.text_parsed: I feel like this card is undervalued in constructed. It is the cornerstone of my GW Humans deck, and I actually prefer to have this card in hand over a Hero of Bladehold in most situations. With 33 creatures in my deck I average 2.8 creatures from this card. Any time I draw 3 or more creatures off this card, the game usually ends in victory within a few turns. With so many creatures in my deck, the odds of drawing no creatures off this are very low. If my math is right, it's about a 1 in 80 chance to blank on this assuming you've drawn 10 cards by the time you play this. I would only recommend playing this in a deck where it is your only non-creature spell, because even adding a few spells from my sideboard can make the odds on this much worse. For example, adding 6 non-creature spells from my sideboard increases the odds of blanking on this to about 1 in 26. Still pretty good odds, but if that's what your deck looks like before sideboarding, it will probably only get worse post board. 5/5 and an easy 4-of in my creature-heavy deck.

249369: Lead the Stampede.author: lungsoftheocean
249369: Lead the Stampede.text_parsed:
While Stampede definitely doesn't fit in just any green-flavored Modern Constructed deck, it is invaluable in certain archetypes. For instance, I roll two of these in Bant Con***ion (not sure why c o n s c r i p t i o n is getting starred out here. Is Eldrazi Con***ion THAT bad of a word nowadays? ;). It sets up creature combos really well. In this case, you can dig turn two for exactly the creatures you need turn three. At this point whatever else you draw is a bonus.

I kept pulling it from that deck thinking, "It's not THAT good" but I always end up splashing it back in because it is so useful when you are in a bind.

For what it does, I'm not sure any other card accomplishes as much for 3 mana.

249378: Grazing Gladehart.author: JaxsonBateman
249378: Grazing Gladehart.text_parsed:
@YokeOfTheDamned - that may be one of the most garbage 'combos' I've ever seen. If you want good lifegain synergy in white, just go with the classic Martyr of Sands and Proclamation of Rebirth for a great lategame lifegain engine. If you want it via Soul Foundry, it's easily done with something like Soul Warden or Essence Warden. Only 1 mana a turn, doesn't require any other cards, and the gain will quickly start stacking up.

@The people talking about comboing with Fastbond - Fastbond combos with an absurd amount of cards. Many players would be happy to pay 5 life to get a turn 1 Baneslayer (Fastbond, 6 lands, Baneslayer, obv on the draw). This card is still weak as; it's the brokenness of Fastbond that can make it an infinite combo.

While I do have fond memories of this guy as I once managed to include him in an infinite life combo (a very janky casual combo, white/green/blue, Ruin Ghost, Tideforce Elemental, Lotus Cobra, Gladehart), combo and lower-power casual are really the only places you can play him. He doesn't really belong in aggro or control; he's too weak for aggro, and doesn't help your board nearly enough for control.

YAY! THE FLAVOR TEXT IS BACK! THANK YOU WIZARDS!!! =D

I always imagined this card as representing the blind eternities. Personally believe that zero decks should not 1-of this. Yes, there are enough better things that even 2-of-ing is probably excessive (aren't you using on-color dual fetches if you're running basics?) but...for the amazing flavor connection with Planeswalkers, the Blind Eternities, Mana Bonds...in other words, all of frikkin MAGIC,


yeah- you need to have one of these in your deck, whether you are playing Standard FNM or Vintage Grand Prix. Opposing Wastelands make it very much playable. At the very least Sideboard.

Terramorphic Expanse and Ghost Quarter are probably the best non-broken utility lands in the game.

249383: Briarhorn.author: AronChan
249383: Briarhorn.text_parsed:
Questions:

Is it possible to Evoke Briarhorn and use it as a blocker before you sacrifice it?

If briarhorn comes into play and recieves the +3/+3 itself. Will it then be counted as a 6/6 towards the use of Pandemonium?
249383: Briarhorn.text_posted:
Questions:

Is it possible to Evoke Briarhorn and use it as a blocker before you sacrifice it?

If briarhorn comes into play and recieves the +3/+3 itself. Will it then be counted as a 6/6 towards the use of [autocard]Pandemonium[/autocard]?

249383: Briarhorn.author: HotHit
249383: Briarhorn.text_parsed:
Aronchan, I'm sorry it took so long for you to get a response. First, steps cannot end until the stack is complete (except by card effects like time stop). So, whether you could declare Briarhorn as a blocker during the block step doesn't matter, since it's sacrificed before it can actually reach the damage step where it will block the creature. So, no you can't evoke a blocker, but whether you can evoke a block declaration I'm unsure of. But I am doubtful of it.

Secondly, pandemonium checks power upon the ability's resolution. Meaning you put the Pandemonium effect on the stack first, followed by the +3/+3. Thus, it resolves the +3/+3 boost first for a total of 6/6 when Pandemonium resolves.
249383: Briarhorn.text_posted:
Aronchan, I'm sorry it took so long for you to get a response. First, steps cannot end until the stack is complete (except by card effects like [autocard]time stop[/autocard]). Secondly, pandemonium checks power upon the ability's resolution. Meaning you put the Pandemonium effect on the stack first, followed by the +3/+3. Thus, it resolves the +3/+3 boost first for a total of 6/6 when Pandemonium resolves.

249383: Briarhorn.author: Antsache
249383: Briarhorn.text_parsed:
@ Hothit, Aronchan

Blockers are declared at the start of the Declare Blockers step, and their declaration does not use the stack. This occurs before players have the chance to cast spells or do anything. The Declare Blockers step begins immediately following the end of the Declare Attackers step. Therefore, there is no time at which you could evoke a creature in order to use it as a blocker. If you do it at the end of the Declare Attackers step, its sacrifice ability will go on the stack and have to resolve before you can proceed to the Declare Blockers step. If you do it at the beginning of the Declare Blockers step, you will have to do it after blockers are declared, and it will be too late to select the evoked creature as a blocker. As noted, in this case its sacrifice ability will resolve before combat damage is dealt, so the creature isn't on the battlefield at the time damage is dealt, either.
249383: Briarhorn.text_posted:
@ Hothit, Aronchan

Blockers are declared at the start of the Declare Blockers step, and their declaration does not use the stack.  This occurs before players have the chance to cast spells or do anything.  The Declare Blockers step begins immediately following the end of the Declare Attackers step.  Therefore, there is no time at which you could evoke a creature in order to use it as a blocker.  If you do it at the end of the Declare Attackers step, its sacrifice ability will go on the stack and have to resolve before you can proceed to the Declare Blockers step.  If you do it at the beginning of the Declare Blockers step, you will have to do it after blockers are declared, and it will be too late to select the evoked creature as a blocker.  As noted, in this case its sacrifice ability will resolve before combat damage is dealt, so the creature isn't on the battlefield at the time damage is dealt, either.

249383: Briarhorn.author: Oblivax
249383: Briarhorn.text_parsed: The first time i saw someone use a blink to get around the evoke sacrifice, I thought it seemed a little fishy, but i let it pass.  If you review the rules, specifically 702.72a, it's very clear that the sacrifice is PART of the casting cost, not a triggered effect.  Failure to sacrifice the creature makes the evoke fizzle and the creature goes to the graveyard.  It doesn't matter if the creature leaves the battlefield, it still must be sacrificed to fulfill the evoke cost. Any judge that misses this obviously hasn't read the rules closely enough.
249383: Briarhorn.text_posted: The first time i saw someone use a blink to get around the evoke sacrifice, I thought it seemed a little fishy, but i let it pass. 249384: Icy Manipulator.author: The_Erudite_Idiot
249384: Icy Manipulator.text_parsed:
The Manipulator is a great example of what a great card is. It can be used well is a great number of decks, but it doesn't ever break the game by itself. Very versatile.
In recent years (the last decade) this card has become less useful, as many old cards have, but it remains very handy. If you are a new player, this is something to experiment with. Scour the internet for this card's usefulness. It never has the best answer to any problem, but it always provides an answer to any problem.
Up there with Birds of Paradise and Lightning Bolt in my book.

249389: Sapseep Forest.author: Crimeo
249389: Sapseep Forest.text_parsed:
Very useful along with Ajani's Pridemate or Archangel of Thune, for example. Both of which trigger their abilities per life gain event, and don't care how much life was gained. Even one life from sapseep gives all your creatures +1/+1 permanent tokens with a Thune out. And since she is a major kill target, you need all the immediate lifegain events you can get on the stack until that removal spell resolves.

Example:
1) I cast Thune. My opponent doesn't have a cancel spell, so she resolves.
2) My opponent does have a doomblade though, and throws it at her immediately.
3) I tap my sapseed forest in response, and it goes on top of doom blade in the stack.
4) Sapseep resolves, Thune's ability then triggers and goes on top of the stack.
5) Thune's ability resolves, all my creatures get their tokens.
6) Then she dies.

Sapseed here would make the difference between, for instance, my massive token army all being permanently twice as powerful, or not.
249389: Sapseep Forest.text_posted:
Very useful along with Ajani's Pridemate or Archangel of Thune, for example. Both of which trigger their abilities per life gain event, and don't care how much life was gained. Even one life from sapseep gives all your creatures +1/+1 permanent tokens with a Thune out.  And since she is a major kill target, you need all the immediate lifegain events you can get on the stack until that removal spell resolves.

Example:
1) I cast Thune. My opponent doesn't have a cancel spell, so she resolves.
2) My opponent does have a doomblade though, and throws it at her immediately.
3) I tap my sapseed forest in response, and it goes on top of doom blade in the stack.
4) Sapseep resolves, Thune's ability then triggers and goes on top of the stack.
5) Thune's ability resolves, all my creatures get their tokens.
6) Then she dies.

Sapseed here would make the difference between, for instance, my massive token army all being permanently twice as powerful, or not.

249391: Fleetfoot Panther.author: Mode
249391: Fleetfoot Panther.text_parsed:
The synergy with Qasali Ambusher is just incredible.

(Example: Given that you have both of them in your hand, at least three mana open and both a forest and a plains (or simply a Savannah or Temple Garden), just wait for your opponent to attack.
Then drop Qasali Ambusher, block one creature, cast Fleetfoot Panther, return the ambusher, and block another creature.
You blocked two creatures and likely destroyed one in the process, and have a 3/4 on the field.
And you'll still be able to potentially recast the ambusher sometime later for free again.)

Then there's also Loam Lion and Savannah Lions...this makes me want to build a cat deck.

Of course there are a lot more of good combos with Fleetfoot Panther if you bounce creatures with etb effects like Leonin Squire (just a random, cat-related idea).

Bouncing one of the temporary Nacatl War-Pride tokens works nicely as well.

He - and also Nacatl War-Pride in particular - also synergize with Healer of the Pride,
particularly if you also play Felidar Souvereign, Ajani's Pridemate or even Ajani himself - fittingly as Caller of the Pride.

249391: Fleetfoot Panther.author: Polarith
249391: Fleetfoot Panther.text_parsed:
@Blurrymadness - he didn't mean that but it is a good way to do it (evidence at the end of his first paragraph.

Easy way to explain this. You cannot cast any spells or activate any abilities during the declare attackers or blockers phase. This means that you must assign all creatures you wish to block with at the same time.

It goes something like this (exact name for phases escape me but this is accurate enough for us to work with:

Start of Combat phase (spells and abilities can be used if available)

Declare attackers phase - All attackers must be declared (no spells or abilities can be used)

Gap before declare blockers phase (spells and abilities can be used if available)

Declare blockers phase - All defenders must be declared (no spells or abilities can be used)

Gap before damage is assigned (spells and abilities can be used if available)

First Strike damage phase - If creatures are present with either first strike or Double strike (no spells or abilities can be used)

Gap before Main damage phase - can be important as some abilities trigger on damage can resolve now and it allows you to play spells or abilities at this point. Also all creatures that have died due to the first strike phase are removed/dealt with.

Main damage phase (no spells or abilities can be used)

End of combat phase / clean up


Hope that is relatively clear. Don't believe there are errors there but happy to discuss.

249393: Vitu-Ghazi, the City-Tree.author: DarthParallax
249393: Vitu-Ghazi, the City-Tree.text_parsed:
This card and Necropotence are probably the two that I would pick to set aside, not actually teach a beginner with, but AFTER they've made a simple 2-color Timmy Beats Deck using any Tribe, AND after I've shown them a relatively ***ed Mono-Red deck, a Zoo Deck (the tournament version of what they tried to build), and a Blue-Black control deck....

THEN- I start attempting to explain why Necropotence is good and how good it is- That it is good takes only using 4x Sign in Bloods in the U/B teaching deck, but HOW good will take a bit longer...:P

THEN- After they are competetent enough at mana curves to build non-shabby theoretical decks with any spoiler, I throw this wierd-@$$ curve ball at em.

It asks you to pay 4 mana, and tap a land...essentially pay 5 mana to get a 1/1 token. HOW can that possibly be good?!?! I remember my brother played a Selesnya Starter deck to my Rakdos one right around when we were starting out the first time- I can't remember if Ravnica or Time Spiral was new at the time, I do remember I had a sweet Sek-Kuar Coldsnap deck. And I thought this land was complete trash.

Years later, I'm reading up on the Ghazi-Glare deck that could fight Affinity and win. I still can't warp my brain around that, but it works. Glare of Subdual is another wierd one. You will stop being a beginner when you understand any two of these cards, and how they are all from the same game and yet all good:

Necropotence, Vitu-Ghazi, and Ironclaw Orcs

249396: Behemoth Sledge.author: PurpGuy
249396: Behemoth Sledge.text_parsed:
I'm not entirely sold on this either, although it is pretty good for an equip.

You gotta pay for it twice - first to put it onto battlefield, then to attach to a creature. So the turn it comes out it may do absolutely nothing for you. Or you hold on to it until you have the 6 mana to make it do something the turn it comes out, but then it's just sitting there in your hand in the meantime... again, doing nothing.

White, Green, and Red all have anti-artifact spells. There goes 6 mana investment down the drain vs a majority of colors. I think the best way to counter "disenchant" effects is to either 1) not take any artifacts/enchantments at all, or 2) take so many artifacts and enchantments that they cannot possibly destroy them all. But spells like Shatterstorm or Fracturing Gust make that option moot.

Sure, you could use some sort of Counterspell to prevent your Artifact from being destroyed, but you can do exactly that to protect an Aura, also. So this point, too, is moot.

Heck, in Alara Block (Where this card came from) my Bant deck has no less than 12 cards that can destroy artifacts. Qasali Pridemage, Naturalize, and Bant Charm. Go ahead, run 4 copies of this in your deck. It will be a waste of space and mana, because I will wait for you to spend the additional 3 mana to equip it to something before I destroy it.

Prefer Armadillo Cloak really, because at least it grants its effects the turn it comes into play, and for half the mana investment.

249398: Ajani's Mantra.author: iUseBreakOpen
249398: Ajani's Mantra.text_parsed: I think Eluem meant to post that comment for Touch of the Eternal because this plus Phyrexian Unlife does NOT make you invulnerable to creature attacks. For example: You have 3 life. You are attack by Avatar of Fury and now you have -3 life. You gain 1 life from this and now you have -2 life. You are attacked again. Since you have <0 life, the damage is treated as though it has infect and you get 6 poison counters. You gain 1 life from this and now you have -1 life. You are attacked again, you get 6 more poison counters and lose. Where's the invulnerability?

249399: Sylvan Ranger.author: james2c19v
249399: Sylvan Ranger.text_parsed:
In mono green, when you don't have a land to play, or when you have something like Skyshroud Ranger on the battlefield, it's basically Nature's Lore on legs. If you do have a land to play, but you won't on your next turn, then it becomes Rampant Growth on legs. If you have a land to play on both this turn and the next, then it does you the favor of getting another land out of your deck (and thereby decreasing the odds of you drawing yet another on your next turn).

In a word: underrated.

249401: Wild Nacatl.author: Minus_Prime
249401: Wild Nacatl.text_parsed: Banned in Modern, not necessarily for being overpowered or for showing up in all the decks, but because its specific land requirements wound up making most of the decks the same. Yes Tarmogoyf is overpowered and sees play everywhere, but that 'everywhere' is a wide range of different builds and play styles. Wild Nacatl fits into only one build, being just good enough at what it does to force all the Modern aggro decks into Naya "Zoo", killing all hope for aggro diversity, and ironically making a drawback with no conceivable upside the root cause of the card's ban.
249401: Wild Nacatl.text_posted: Banned in Modern, not necessarily for being overpowered or for showing up in all the decks, but because its specific land requirements wound up making most of the decks the same. [autocard]Wild Nacatl[/autocard] fits into only one build, being just good enough at what it does to force all the Modern aggro decks into [RGW] Naya "Zoo", killing all hope for aggro diversity, and ironically making a drawback with no conceivable upside the root cause of the card's ban.

249404: Slavering Nulls.author: DarthParallax
249404: Slavering Nulls.text_parsed:
Bounce + Discard is good if you are playing a more tactical than strategic game. If you expect the game to go long, think C.A. If you are trying to race with a low-end midrange deck, though, then the synergy of bounce and discard is the same thing as Strip Mining a Ravnica Karoo land- tempo, tempo, tempo.

Assume Blue-Black zombies vs. Red-Green goblins and elves

1. you play a land and a creature (some zombie), he plays a land and a creature (some elf)

2. you play island and bounce his creature then attack, he replays his creature and a land.

3. you play another island, bounce, and duress that same creature again and attack, he plays a land.

4. you play another creature, and now get 2 attacks a turn. he still has nothing up but lands.


It's not something to use every day, because spending 3 cards to beat one is technically resource disadvantage (both cards and mana), but if you can lay on heavy disruption early, you can put him far behind.

And the REASON you would do this instead of just plain kill it is that bounce and discard both come at one-mana, but killing nearly always takes 2. we will not speak of Dismember. that didn't happen.

bounce and discard on 1 mana, creatures on 1,2, and 3 mana (doesn't matter if they're weak), and countering, killing and drawing on 2 and 3 mana = a more than decent deck

249405: Qasali Pridemage.author: blurrymadness
249405: Qasali Pridemage.text_parsed:
One of the many reasons green is so nice to have in legacy. A 1-of of this guy with GSZ can get you out some serious problems. He's quite balanced still; and pretty necessary to have around. Being able to kill off Batterskull while not necessarily winning the 2, or even 1-drop fights makes him pretty on par.

The difference between his card parity and Junds card advantage (which was everywhere) is part of the reason Jund so dominated; another part was Putrid Leech. Right next to this guy's ability to attack for 3 was a 2-drop who could attack or block as a 4. That set demonstrated how much more power you deserve to get for each additional color.

Each creature pushed boundaries and many saw play in several formats; some still do!

I'm not sure what the point would be if they printed this as a mythic... I, for one, am happy that I can get such a nice card relatively cheaply due to it being common.

I doubt that anyone can deny that this card is very good. Hard to play around too. You can run out your target in order to kill it (and trade badly) or you can sit there and let the 3/3 hit you repeatedly.

249405: Qasali Pridemage.author: RobotOwl
249405: Qasali Pridemage.text_parsed:
Every time I look at this card I cannot help but think that Wizards originally planned on it being two separate creatures. One with Exalted and the other with the artifact/enchantment destruction. Especially since it is a common.

One cannot ask for more utility in a single creature. Creatures with similar levels of utility usually rely on some other source to make it good. For example, Deathrite Shaman needs the graveyard or it is just a 1/2, and Stoneforge Mystic is only as good as the equipment it gets. Also note that these cards are rares.

Of course I am not saying that Qasali Pridemage is better than these two, but my point is that this card is good by itself. It attacks as Watchwolf and is constantly threatening any of your opponents artifacts or enchantments. It is pretty much required as a 1 or 2 of in any GW deck, especially with Green Sun's Zenith.

5/5 for being an awesome card but still far from broken.

249407: Elder Mastery.author: Hercynian
249407: Elder Mastery.text_parsed:
I think of auras like this as creatures. So this creature is a 6cmc 3/3 with haste, flyng, and the ability to make an opponent discard two cards when it gies off.

So lets say 3/3 flying for 3 cmc is good, and haste adds an extra 1 cmc, then his ability (which is hard to assign) maybe adds 1cmc because it's conditional on damage and late game when hands are likely exhausted. Also, the color requirement is quite stiff so that should reduce the cost by 1, but this is in Alara block so that is negated enough to make it irrelevant. That adds up to a total of 5cmc. So it's overcoatsted by one if it was a creature. However it is not, this brings some other factors into the equation:

Being an enchantment means that it is grafted onto another creature, potentially providing a 2 for one kill spell or other nasty effects (-2 cmc). However being an enchantment actually has some advantages of its own that need to be factored in. It can be placed on a creature that has double strike, an ability not uncommon for red, it can interact with various enchantment based card effects like auramancer (not that that would be synergistic), it can be placed on some kind of unblockable creature like dread warlock or invisible stalker (+1 cmc bringing total to -1cmc)

So in summary this card would be pretty competitive at a cost of 4cmc. At 6cmc it would need some other thing attached that would make up for the difference, like totem armor, or intimidate instead of flying for example.

I like the concept of making up for the lack of card advantage that auras net by making opponents discard cards. I think it would go under the radar of magic players conditioned to onlyblike auras with totem armor or "return to hand" clauses. Alas, you come close, but you fall too short, my friend with excellent flavor text. I'll play you anyway just for that reason!

249411: Ageless Entity.author: Lifegainwithbite
249411: Ageless Entity.text_parsed:
I run lifegain but I don't like this card for several reasons:

1) It's just big. No trample, doesn't gain you life and is usually chump blocked every turn. There's plenty of bigger and better stuff. Wolfir Silverheart for example, especially when soulbonded to something with trample (Pathbreaker Wurm?). Wolfir costs the same too.

2) No protection at all and that effect just screams 'Remove me now'. Most effects that beg to be removed do that because they're insane (like Felidar Sovereign) but this one does just cause it's big and people overestimate big things.

3) Doesn't actually gain you any life. I know people are talking about Armadillo Cloak but let's face it, Armadillo Cloak is an amazing card in general and there are many better creatures you can put that on.(something with lifegain already for example so you gain double the life. Again Felidar Sovereign anyone?)

The only use I can really see out of this is to waste your opponents' removal and there's plenty of better ways to do that (Ajani's Pridemate will be killed pretty quickly too. It has the same problems as this card but is playable because it's 2 mana and you want big stuff at 2 mana). Or you can waste 5 mana so your opponent spends 2 to remove it. 2.5/5.

249414: Loxodon Hierarch.author: kameenook
249414: Loxodon Hierarch.text_parsed: I have 2 questions about this card for one correct me if I'm wrong but when you regenerate him you do not get his gain 4 life ability again. Number 2 would he be sacrificed before he could get a regeneration shield?
249414: Loxodon Hierarch.text_posted: I have 2 questions about this card for one correct me if I'm wrong but when you regenerate him you do not get his gain 4 life ability again. Number 2 would he be sacrificed before he could get a regeneration shield?

249414: Loxodon Hierarch.author: Dark_Raider
249414: Loxodon Hierarch.text_parsed:
@kameenook: Regenerate does not bring creatures into play again: it merely stops them from being destroyed. As such, the 'enters-the-battlefield'-ability would not trigger again, and you would not gain 4 life.

Second, regenerate only stops permanents (creatures in this case) being destroyed. Sacrifice is not a destruction effect: as such, it gets past regeneration-shields and even indestructible creatures.

Third, you pay the cost for a spell or ability before that spell or ability resolves. In this case, the Hierarch would be sacrificed before his regeneration ability ever actually happened. This also means that you can't use destroy effects, etc. to stop him from using the ability: before those destroy effects resolved, he would already be sacrificed.

EDH:

Friend: "I'll play Knowledge Exploitation. Hey, look! Cruel Ultimatum!"

259262: Cruel Ultimatum.author: Lifegainwithbite
259262: Cruel Ultimatum.text_parsed:
@rancidraptor: Someone needs to play magic a bit more if they think gaining 5 life when the game is about to end is going to help much. Someone needs to play magic a bit more if they think a lava axe for 7 mana is worth it.
Someone needs to play magic a bit more if they think drawing three cards will save them if they've already tapped out to use this and are about to die. And no, this isn't helpful in any format except casual. Someone has obviously never played a tournament in their life and has no idea what it involves. Card advantage is awesome but not when it consumes all your mana and you're left with nothing till next turn.

@Stig: Yeah but you wouldn't be able to use the damnation till next turn and by the time you get to this amount of mana, you'll die too fast to use it or you won't need it.

@iharbinger: I've had it played on me and still won because I had a powerful enough board presence. Plus it was a dead card in my opponent's hand for the first 15 minutes of the game.

However, I can see this being useful for edh, perhaps with Nicol Bolas as general. But even then, in edh you want things that make everyone else discard or sacrifice, not just one person. 259262: Cruel Ultimatum.author: Continue
259262: Cruel Ultimatum.text_parsed:
­It's a combination of Cruel Edict, Fugue, Disentomb, Concentrate, and (almost) Stolen Grain (using this instead of Rhystic Siphon because, well, that's a Rhystic spell). These five cards together cost . You're paying for their five effects together.

Let that sink in. You've paid 7 mana for 18 mana worth of effects. It would be fair at (12 mana) to put it into perspective.

Card advantage: +7 this is effectively a 4 for -3.
Life advantage: +10 people say lifegain doesn't mean much, and in this case it's the least of the six effects, but even then it's good.
Mana cost: You would be surprised by how easily this can be cast with such a restrictive mana cost. 7 colored mana is easy as hell in Modern, where we have shocklands among other things. For the first year this was out, there were the Shadowmoor/Eventide filter lands (Graven Cairns et al.) in Standard, as well as Reflecting Pool.
Devastation: Let's just say that when this card hits the table, it goes thud. It is Grixis's bomb. It will kill you. And it will be glorious. 5/5

It's multicolorness (sorta) and kicker templating really allowed them to make a much, much more interesting take on Terror/Doom Blade.  Against Ajani, who is basically running Zoo Lightsaber, I would probably prefer Doom Blade, but I would absolutely keep one of these ready against Garruk and Overwhelming Stampede. It's really a fine card for control players to consider running. What's the point of running control anyway if you don't get to use more mana?

259269: Dimir Cutpurse.author: psychichobo
259269: Dimir Cutpurse.text_parsed:
I wanna like this guy, but the term 'Draw a card' on a permanent tends to get it marked for removal pretty quickly. Plus, you have to give him some kind of support.

I'm comparing him to Child of Night, who has a similar function in that it's got that 'Do you really want to lose a creature to prevent a measly two damage and me getting two life?' ability. This can't boast the same, since the ability is so good you WILL trade the creature. With the Child, a lot of people I saw playing it had it quite late into the game, by which time it had already hit at least twice, then chump blocked for 4 damage, 6 life and damage prevention.

Give him Mask of Riddles, watch your opponents sweat. He does need a boost sadly, but he rocks with it. In fact, isn't that Mastery enchantment in this deck? Perfect target.

259271: Grixis Charm.author: RiftenBlack
259271: Grixis Charm.text_parsed:
This is a very mediocre charm.

In these colours, I like the Boomerang effect, even though it costs 1 more mana. I'm willing to sacrifice efficiency here if the other 2 modes are also good. Unfortunately, they aren't.

Giving a creature -4/-4 is often not efficient enough. When cards like Path to Exile, Terminate, etc. exist for just a few mana to kill almost anything, this removal spell looks very lackluster. While this can kill indestructible creatures, it can't even kill a Tarmogoyf most of the time, making it pretty bad.

The last mode is almost never useful in these colours, unless you're playing some kind of limited format. In 2013, that's not likely.

Since the Boomerang effect is a turn slow, it's also not as powerful as Boomerang is either. I'd pass on this.

259272: Shriekmaw.author: Oblivax
259272: Shriekmaw.text_parsed: The first time i saw someone use a blink to get around the evoke sacrifice, I thought it seemed a little fishy, but i let it pass.  If you review the rules, specifically 702.72a, it's very clear that the sacrifice is PART of the casting cost, not a triggered effect.  Failure to sacrifice the creature makes the evoke fizzle and the creature goes to the graveyard.  It doesn't matter if the creature leaves the battlefield, it still must be sacrificed to fulfill the evoke cost. Any judge that misses this obviously hasn't read the rules closely enough.
259272: Shriekmaw.text_posted: The first time i saw someone use a blink to get around the evoke sacrifice, I thought it seemed a little fishy, but i let it pass.  If you review the rules, specifically 702.72a, it's very clear that the sacrifice is PART of the casting cost, not a triggered effect.  Failure to sacrifice the creature makes the evoke fizzle and the creature goes to the graveyard.  It doesn't matter if the creature leaves the battlefield, it still must be sacrificed to fulfill the evoke cost. Any judge that misses this obviously hasn't read the rules closely enough.

259272: Shriekmaw.author: WhiteWizard42
259272: Shriekmaw.text_parsed:
Oblivax - " If you review the rules, specifically 702.72a, it's very clear that the sacrifice is PART of the casting cost, not a triggered effect. Failure to sacrifice the creature makes the evoke fizzle and the creature goes to the graveyard. "

Comp Rules 702.72a - "When this permanent enters the battlefield, if its evoke cost was paid, its controller sacrifices it."

It's a triggered ability that triggers if the evoke cost was paid, so 1) it triggers at the same time as the "ETB, terror" ability, but they are separate abilities and have no effect on each other's resolving, and 2) if a creature leaves play and comes back, it is treated as a new object. The sacrifice doesn't apply because it's not the same creature any more. The "sacrifice this" trigger still resolves, but the permanent it applies to no longer exists, so it does nothing. Check rule 400.7 for more details, and to find out what the exceptions actually are.

Dragonmaster, if rumors prove to be true, you're in luck. A highly reliable (albeit unconfirmed) source has stated that we're going back to the greatest plane of all. Ravnica. That'll be the block after Innistrad.

EDIT: Reading about Izzet, it's mechanic articles says "So even though the costs are all the same this time around, the door is open for significant tweaking when we inevitably return to this mechanic." Of course, the Guildpact fell, but in "Agents of Artifice," it's shown that past ties to guilds still matter.

259275: Profane Command.author: XaiviarNightwing
259275: Profane Command.text_parsed:
Radiate. For each possible target it is copied and 2 effects are selected.
Each player loses X life.
Each creature gets -X/-X.
For each of those targets you may return a creature with converted manna cost X or less From your graveyard to the battlefield.
Resolve copies on your creatures first then bring them back. The first creature isn't cause it hasn't hit the grave yet but when you lose the life he comes back.
Then kill opponents creatures and bring back another of yours. Then your opponent takes the life hit.
With Deathgreeter in play you gain 1 life for each creature that died except him. If you had creatures that are vengeful when they die they go off and when they come back even more activated abilities. And that is for a board wipe. That is how you go black and never go black.
Wrath of Rakdos
X3RRBB
Discard Profane Command and Radiate: Exile the will to live from each opponent.
Johnny eat your heart out.
P.S. works because you are only targeting 1 permanent or player with each copy, cards in the graveyard are not permanents, and Radiate unlike most other copy cards doesn't reduce X to zero.
Use Deathgreeter, Apprentice Necromancer, Carnival of Souls. for the X3BB so all you need is BRR to start the party.
259275: Profane Command.text_posted:
[autocard]Radiate[/autocard]. For each possible target it is copied and 2 effects are selected.
Each player loses X life.
Each creature gets -X/-X.
For each of those targets you may return a creature with converted manna cost X or less From your graveyard to the battlefield.
Resolve copies on your creatures first then bring them back. The first creature isn't cause it hasn't hit the grave yet but when you lose the life he comes back.
Then kill opponents creatures and bring back another of yours. Then your opponent takes the life hit.
With [autocard]Deathgreeter[/autocard] in play you gain 1 life for each creature that died except him. If you had creatures that are vengeful when they die they go off and when they come back even more activated abilities. And that is for a board wipe. That is how you go black and never go black.
Wrath of Rakdos
X3RRBB
Discard Profane Command and Radiate: Exile the will to live from each opponent.
Johnny eat your heart out.
P.S. works because you are only targeting 1 permanent or player with each copy, cards in the graveyard are not permanents, and Radiate unlike most other copy cards doesn't reduce X to zero.
Use Deathgreeter, [autocard]Apprentice Necromancer[/autocard], [autocard]Carnival of Souls[/autocard]. for the X3BB so all you need is BRR to start the party.

259275: Profane Command.author: Lifegainwithbite

One of the three unbelievably powerful commands:
Cryptic Command - probably the best for any control deck.
Profane Command - great for any graveyard-based deck, a great finisher and removal when you need it.
Primal Command - decent lifegain in a desperate situation, creature tutoring and removal when you need it.

259276: Slave of Bolas.author: thought_jar
259276: Slave of Bolas.text_parsed:
Sabrina felt herself sink slowly to the academy floor. The icy bindings on her mind were beginning to transform into a smiley warmth over her tormenting recollections. What cruel force could marionette her to the recruitment halls, unable to scream as she politely asked the new recruits to present arms? Through the nauseating shame and muffled cries of the new watch, that same reptilian voice wormed around between her ears.
"How was it Sabrina? Don't worry, it'll be over soon."

259278: Undermine.author: DarthParallax
259278: Undermine.text_parsed:
Possibly the best 'strictly better than cancel' in the game, in the context of everything you ever knew about counterspells.

3 mana is about where you want counterspells sitting if you want to have a deck that can interact with a variety of decks without causing to many 'unfun' moments, while still giving it a good chance to play control. If nobody will PLAY against your Force of Will deck, then you've actually LOST by winning too much. see?

whereas this is just 'difficult' enough to cast (2 colors! :O 3 mana! :O ) that they can't really not let you use it....but evil enough that you will cackle every time it hits the stack :)
(PS signets are awesome :D )

259278: Undermine.author: blurrymadness
259278: Undermine.text_parsed:
When control and aggro collide, you get this: Win conditions stapled to counterspells. Yeah.

Building myself Suicide/Aggro blue around cards like this. When you consider that this, Countersquall, Mind Bomb, and Psionic Blast are a total of 48 damage in 16 cards; then add in beautifully efficient blue flying beaters, it's not hard to see why it could brutalize many decks without trying. Blue's library manipulation, card draw, and efficient damage cards like these make it almost as good as red at burn, except it counters combo, and doesn't rely on removal to keep creatures out.

Keeping black in the deck allows one to side in a boatload of efficient black removal, weenie killers and gravehate. Think Go for the Throat, Plague Spitter, Shriekmaw, Leyline of the Void, etc..

259278: Undermine.author: Ferlord
259278: Undermine.text_parsed:
So I was playing a game with my bud, and we both were playing EDH decks with in it. We both played Undermine.

So at one time, I played Knowledge Pool, which exiled his Undermine. Then he played Knowledge pool (we have similar decks) and exiled his.

After that, I kind of conceded because... well, two god-damned knowledge pools? Sorry bro, no can do.

But then as we were cleaning up, I lost count of which undermine was mine. We had the same coloured sleeves, you see (NO, WE AREN'T THE SAME PERSON).

So he asks, "Which pool is my undermine exiled with?"

I said, "Well, I think it's under mine."

A second passed.

I then stood up, took a deep breath, and said, "I... think I have to go now."


Magic Puns.

259279: Obelisk of Grixis.author: DarthParallax
259279: Obelisk of Grixis.text_parsed:
Gem of Becoming. Probably arguably better than Manalith because of many lands that have basic types but aren't basics. there's at least 25 of them, but maybe more:

ABU Dual Land Cycle, which is OK

Ravnica Shock Cycle, which I like more for Art, Balance, Flavor, and Synergies: (especially in Green White, if you are trying to get your life total to a specific number, Shocking yourself and then gaining life is more reliable than large swings of life in Black with lifelink and costs)
-Basically I argue 'More Text = More Fun if the text actually does something relevant and they aren't just being wordy for something simple'.

And there are some cards in Shadowmoor that have only one type that are fetchable with the Gem, like Moonring Island.

Gem can get you quite a lot of value, and I almost wish there was a powerful artifact like it but different that went for another set of lands, but then people would want a cycle, and it isn't something we need to give Commanders more than 1 or 2 of in their decks.

266154: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.author: DarthParallax
266154: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.text_parsed:
Alright, who's the wise guy that didn't give Mr. Bolas 5 stars? Pay mana, get win. Simple! Well, you asked for it.....if there were room, this would be his flavor text:

"I must admit, Your parlor tricks are amusing! I bet You've got a beeble under your hat! Now here's your chance to get the best of me,
Hope your hand is HOT!, C'mon clown, Let's see what You've Got!"

"You try to shock me with your hardest stuff but your Double Whammy isn't up to Snuff! I'll set the record straight--You're simply out of date
You're only Second Rate!
You think your cat's a monster, but your tiger's tame; You've got a lot to learn About the Magic game So for your information, I'll Reiterate-
You're only Second Rate!"

"Men cower at the power in my pinky!!! My thumb is #1 on every list!
But if you're not convinced that I'M INVINCIBLE, Put me to the test! I'd love to lay this Rivalry to Rest!!!
Go ahead and Zap me with the 'big surprise', Snap me in a Trap, Cut me down to Size!
I'll make a Big Escape- it's just a piece of Cake!
You're only SECOND RATE!"

"You know, your hocus-pocus isn't tough enough- and your mumbo-jumbo doesn't measure up-
Let me Pontificate upon your Sorry State
You're only SECOND RATE!!!!!!
Alakazam-da-mus and this thing's bigger than the both of us!
So spare me your tremendous scare! You look horrendous in your underwear!
And I can hardly wait, to discombobulate!
I'll send ya back and packing in a shipping CRATE! You'll make a better living with a spinning PLATE!
You're only SECOND RATE!!!!!!"

Other cards I wanted to auto-card into this, but don't know how to blend into the song :/
Pontificate->Ponder
Cat-> Ajani Vengeant
Tame-> Diminish
Invincible-> Indestructible
Mana Leak somewhere
Time Reversal somewhere
Discombobulate->Dismember
Zap-> Lightning Bolt
and the last 'Second Rate' to Glimpse the Unthinkable

Edit: found a pic I to share:
http://browse.deviantart.com/?qh=&section=&q=Jafar+#/d23ltn6

266154: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.author: drpvfx
266154: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.text_parsed:
Perhaps not the "best" Planeswalker overall,
but very arguably the most powerful.

All three of his abilities, including his +3,
are BRUTAL.
Very few decks are safe from any of his powers.

His ultimate is... Ultimate. I'd say it's tied with Jace, the Mind Sculptor for most powerful Ultimate.

His casting cost is a hurdle, but do you really expect such power to come cheaply?
If so, use with Eureka.

I fantasize about one day having Bolas, Conflux, Eureka, and plenty of mana at my disposal:
Cast Conflux, draw Jace, Chandra, Lilliana, Garruk, and Elspeth.
Cast Eureka, play the other five, then play this Master Schemer (mmm, flavor!)
Proceed to make your opponent *very* unhappy,
especially if you already have a Doubling Season or Gilder Bairn in play...

266154: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.author: Ali-Baba
266154: Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker.text_parsed:
Another storyline thought:
There's 3 major evils running around in Magic right now: Bolas, Eldrazi, and Phyrexia. What makes Bolas stand out is he is keeping tabs on the other two, which both happen to be world-consuming evils.

Tezzeret is on New Phyrexia to "Prevent leadership from taking hold", While Sarkhan was sent to Zendikar to awaken the Eldrazi, all Bolas's plans.

Could it be that Nicol Bolas, being the manipulator of worlds that he is, is going to use the other superevils to carry out his own schemes? Or maybe he's going to pit them against each other, the Phyrexians vs the Eldrazi, to see which world-destroying evil is the most powerful...And therefore the most fitting for him to direct to his own purposes?

All Planeswalkers shall kneel before the omnipotent Lord Bolas.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

At any rate though, Lord Bolas is a superior villain.

266299: Ajani Vengeant.author: DarthParallax
266299: Ajani Vengeant.text_parsed:
The only planeswalker in the history of the multiverse to ever really WIN a duel with Nicol Bolas. Gotta respect that. (anyone citing preMending history: that's like PreCrisis DCU trivia. A- most of it isn't true anymore, and B- it happened so long ago nobody remembers how it really happened and C- if they don't have a card, and their name's not Urza, I don't really care. Urza needs a card. The rest can be lost to time for all I care.)

Neokoda, that's a terrible design, really. "+1 to win the game"? utterly obsoletes the rest of the card. That could be a fun MINUS ability though. Urza is not dead. His spark/spirit lives on in Karn the Liberated, as you can see in Distant Memories.


Here, let me show you how to design a Stupidly Powerful Planeswalker that manages to remain interesting: (The Creative idea is that this is what Bolas would look like if he regained his PreMending strength somehow.)

Nicol Bolas, Stupidly Powerful Planeswalker * (CMC 25)
(with a clear, Eldrazi frame, and artwork that has a dark background. try it out in MSE, it looks EPIC)
Planeswalker- Bolas
Nicol Bolas, Stupidly Powerful Planeswalker costs less to cast
for each land you control that could produce more than one color of mana.

+4: Destroy target land. That land's controller adds three mana in any combination of colors
to his or her mana pool.

-10: Exile Nicol Bolas, then take two extra turns after this one. At the beginning of the end step
of the second extra turn, return Nicol Bolas to the battlefield under your control.

-20: Your opponents lose the game.

Starting Loyalty: 8

And THAT'S how you make a Stupidly Poweful Planeswalker that is worded just so-
so that it is almost scary possible it could see print.

266299: Ajani Vengeant.author: gman92
266299: Ajani Vengeant.text_parsed:
To those who are saying that Ajani beats Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker any day:
1: Planeswalkers, on average, don't activate their ultimates. Comparing planeswalkers by comparing ultimates is a bad way to compare them. Jace the Mind Sculptor isn't amazing because his ultimate wins you the game. He's amazing because of all the advantage he generates while he's out. I'll take destroying permanents over keeping them tapped down any day.
2: Nicol gets his ultimate on his third turn out. Ajani gets his on his fifth.
3: Nicol's first ability outright gets rid of Ajani AND adds loyalty.
Ajani is land removal a long time from now. Nicol is anything but creature removal NOW.
Nicol>Ajani

266299: Ajani Vengeant.author: kiseki
266299: Ajani Vengeant.text_parsed:
I love love love planeswalkers that defend themselves. He has two abilities that can immediately protect himself from a threat, and an achievable ultimate that will really wreck your opponent's day. And after a Wrath effect, you can hold important land down.
My only dissatisfaction with this guy is in multiplayer. He is so focused at hosing a single player, that he seems lackluster in a game of 6 people.
Best moment: top-decking him when an opponent stabilized and gained control of the battlefield at 2 life.

266299: Ajani Vengeant.author: Wisdomseyes
266299: Ajani Vengeant.text_parsed:
@Gman92:

If we are going to compare planeswalkers side by side and say that the 8 mana 3 color with a 2 black color weight planeswalker has better abilities overall and pretend the mana cost means nothing, then yes, Nico Bolas is by far the best planeswalker (which makes sense because he is the most feared, most powerful, and oldest of the planeswalkers in the fluff)

In terms of which is more likely to come out sooner and effect the game early enough to matter, ajani is better.

In terms of overall loyalty maintaining abilities and flexibility with the ability to kill things with no issues and give you total card advantage, Nico Bolas wins out.

I agree with point 1.

Point 2 contradicts directly with point one. Additionally, it takes 4 turns to get ajani out, and assuming you can consistently get mana, 8 turns for Bolas. Assuming no ramps for the reason neither walker has green and so ramping mana is few and fleeting (though Bolas's color allows for control, meaning lots of land and blue/ black allows for drawing where red/white does not often)

Point 3 assumes they are VS each other (which i can accept because that's what your post alludes to). However, Ajani's +1 is very flexable aside from land control, though land control is admittedly what it will be doing. Bolas does win out with his being a +3 rather than a +1

Fluffwise Bolas > ajani

Gamewise, they both have benefits to the game that match their color perfectly. Bolas is made for control (+ non creature removal{red}, - mind control{blue}, ultimate Pox equivalent{Black}) Ajani is made for aggro (+1 slow down the opponent, law and order {white}, -2 Lightning Helix, ultimate Armageddon combine with targeting the opponent. As both red and white do.

266299: Ajani Vengeant.author: Dr.Pingas
266299: Ajani Vengeant.text_parsed: RunedServitor puts my only feelings pretty clear. I've never played him in 1-1 standard, and I hear he shines there, but as a card as a whole, he seems pretty crappy. His first ability is, well, okay, although extremely out-of-color, and easy to work around - you're not really slowing them down by a turn, when it took you one to play him; you break even. His -2 ability just costs too much loyalty, compared to Sorin's +2 which does the same thing, with only one point less on both sides. His Ultimate does basically say "Target player loses", but it kinda seems like a cheesy cop-out, and pretty out-of-flavor too - white only gets equal-opportunity land destruction, and the same is true of red, although it gets targeted land destruction as well. I really don't get where they got that ability from, or how it's supposed to make sense.

266299: Ajani Vengeant.text_parsed:
Note: for those "TL;DR" people, just read the bottom lines.

In all truth, I don't really like this Ajani as much as almost all of the other planeswalkers. He doesn't have the same memorability as others, because I can't see many people using him in large games like EDH or Two-Headed Giant.

His +1 is deceiving, because "Target thing doesn't become untapped until who-knows-when" are usually at instant speed. You have to make sure that when you use this, you're either using it on a tapped permanent, or just to get to the one-sided Armageddon/more Lightning Helix's.

Although Lightning Helix is a great spell, It doesn't have the weight and magnitude as some others. I'd rather compare his middle negative ability to other similarly-costed 'walkers. Here's some that are technically better:

Koth of the Hammer: Add = your mountains. Turn 4, that gives you back the investment while keeping Koth alive. Late game, you ramp like Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary.

Tezzeret, Agent of Bolas: You could turn a Mox Opal into a 5/5. Do also remember that non-creature artifacts don't have summoning sickness, so Agent can surprise-buttsecks someone if you'd like.

Chandra, the Firebrand: Reverberate, except not a tricky. Since this is situational, Helix may sometimes be better. However, having a permanent Reverberate without paying mana when you're going to cast it is really, REALLY good.

Sorin, Lord of Innistrad: Puts an indestructible, untargetable Orcish Oriflamme. And you can put as many as you want on the field. Uhhh... next planeswalker???

Sarkhan Vol: Act of Treason. It's a situational spell, so I can say Helix is better, but Vol's +1 is REALLY good, and near-completely overshadows the -2.

Ajani Goldmane: Give all your creatures +1/+1 counters AND vigilance? Uhh... Sorry Serra Avatar ability...


So, to summarize, I do think Vengeant is good, just not big-game good.

And that's why I don't like him.

266299: Ajani Vengeant.author: Lifegainwithbite
266299: Ajani Vengeant.text_parsed:
@Ferlord: I disagree on several counts.
1) Non-creature artifacts DO have summoning sickness if they are made creatures. If the artifact has not been in play for at least a turn, you can't make it a creature and attack with it.
2) I think you're underestimating the power of a free Lightning Helix every turn. There's a reason Lightning Bolt is one of the highest-rated and most feared spells in magic. Sure a sorcery-speed lightning bolt is a lot weaker but in Boros aggro decks, that 3 damage will go a long way. Plus the free 3 life (although not particularly useful in an aggro deck) could be useful for staying alive.
3) The ultimate ends any single-player game. If you proliferate that ultimate, that alone is a win condition. I often use Tezzeret's Gambit and other proliferates alongside it. It's pretty much the most powerful ultimate.
4) The +1 ability while situational could stop your opponents attacking Ajani long enough for Ajani to ultimate. Plus if you have no other targets, you could use it on lands which could really slow your opponent down.
Ajani could be a great replacement for used alongisde the new Firemane Angel. You have to take into consideration what kind of decks will be running this card before you judge it.

Ajani is a very powerful planeswalker. While not the best by far, he's a great asset for any Boros deck, aggro or control. I'd give him a 4/5.

266299: Ajani Vengeant.author: Enelysios
266299: Ajani Vengeant.text_parsed:
I will argue that Vengeant is one of the top five planeswalkers, (In terms of power) and that he is potent not just in single player, but multiplayer as well. Forcompetative constructed formats, it is hard to justify high costing spells unless you can cheat them out (Not overly easy for walkers, and you would rather spend most cards that can do it on a combo piece or game ender.) Ajani costs , which is playable. Sure, he has to compete with Jace, the format-sculptor at , and he clearly loses that comparison, but that doesn't mean he is useless. Especially in modern, where Jace is banned.

Any good planeswalker also needs a plus/neutral ability that can effect the board or protect itself. Vengeant has that, and its an ability that gets more potent the better the cards people are playing with. If locking down someone's island or Thragtusk is good, locking down a key part of a competitive deck like a Tolarian Academy, Tarmogoyf or Kiki-Jiki, Mirror Breaker (If they play it before another combo piece) is devastating. In Multiplayer, locking down a major threat or an EDH general against the top player on the board will win political points, stall a game and direct attention away from you.

The secondary ability is even better in Competitive environments. Utility dorks like Dark Confidant, Deathrite Shaman or Lord of Atlantis all die to the bolt and net you 3 life. When the chips are down, Ajani can act like a lightning Helix, and that removal and utility is amazing. Easily one of the top -2s in the game, and its on a costing 'walker. In multiplayer its a bit less impressive, since higher casting creatures rule these formats and tend to have at least 4 toughness.

The ultimate is very ultimate. Ultimates rarely get off in any format, but they have to appear as a threat to be dealt with to keep pressure on your opponents. A one sided Armageddon is that kind of threat. If it goes off, the player it targets is liable to lose in short order. It takes a very commanding board position to survive a hit like that. In multiplayer, it calls the vultures in. Play it and watch as players flock to cremate the man with no response spells.

In single player Ajani Vengeant helps control the board and presents an alt-wincon. In Multiplayer, he stalls and plays politics. A solid choice in a wide variety of decks running Boros colors, and especially at home in control.
